questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following hormones is secreted by the zona glomerulosa?
questions.explanation:
The zona glomerulosa secretes aldosterone. The adrenal cortex has three zones. From outer to inner, they are: • Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (Aldosterone) • Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (Cortisol and corticosterone) • Zona reticularis: Secretes sex steroids (dehydroepiandrosterone, androstenedione, estrogens, 
and glucocorticoids) The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not required for the formation of estradiol?
questions.explanation:
11 hydroxylase is not required for estradiol synthesis. 11 hydroxylase is required for the conversion of 11-deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone, a 
compound formed in the mineralocorticoid synthesis pathway. 735

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is statements is false?

options.a: 90% of the cortisol is bound to plasma proteins
options.b: Cortisol has a half-life of 60-90 minutes.
options.c: Aldosterone has a half-life of about 20 minutes.
options.d: 80% of the aldosterone is bound to plasma proteins

questions.explanation:
60% of aldosterone is bound to plasma proteins, not 80%. 90% of cortisol is bound to plasma proteins. Most of it is bound to transcortin, a 
corticosteroid-specific  2 globulin, and the rest to albumin. This high degree of binding to plasma 
proteins slows the elimination of cortisol. Therefore, cortisol has a longer half-life of 60 to 90 
minutes. Since only about 60% of aldosterone is in bound form, it has a relatively short half-life of about 20 
minutes.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not an action of cortisol?
questions.explanation:
Cortisol suppresses the proliferation of T-lymphocytes and decreases the number of 
T-Lymphocytes. Actions of Cortisol: Metabolic effects: • Effect on carbohydrates: Exert an anti-insulin effect, leading to hyperglycemia • Increases gluconeogenesis • Increases glycogen synthesis • Decreases utilization of glucose in peripheral tissues • Effect on fat and appetite: promotes mobilization of fatty acids from adipose tissue in acute 
states. This mobilization increases the concentration of free fatty acids in the plasma, which also 
increases their utilization for energy, causing lipolysis. However, in chronic states cortisol 
increases appetite and food intake by inducing the synthesis of neuropeptide-Y which leads to an 
apparent lipogenic effect seen as buffalo humping and central obesity. • Effect on protein: Exerts a catabolic effect and causes proteolysis • Effect on water and electrolytes: Sodium water retention and diuresis Anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects: • Induce the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2 • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin • Inhibit the production of IL-2 and T lymphocytes, and depress cellular immunity Maintenance of vascular responsiveness to catecholamines: • Cortisol up-regulates  1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to the vasoconstrictor 
effect of norepinephrine

questions.question:
Question 6: A 60-year-old man is being treated for severe COVID with dexamethasone. Which of the 
following mechanisms best explain the rationale for starting steroids in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Inhibition of phospholipase A2 is an anti-inflammatory effect of steroids, thus being the rationale 
for starting steroids in this patient. Patients with severe COVID are at high risk of developing a systemic inflammatory response. 
Steroids help in mitigating these deleterious effects. Phospholipase A2 is a precursor of arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid is the precursor for 
prostaglandins and leukotrienes, which are involved in inflammation. Steroids induce the 
synthesis of lipocortin, which inhibits phospholipase A2. Other anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects of steroids are: • Inhibit the production of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and proliferation of T lymphocytes • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin from mast cells and platelets

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following effects is produced only at high levels of glucocorticoids?

options.b: Increased excretion of a water load

questions.explanation:
Inhibition of inflammatory response requires high levels of glucocorticoids. Anti-inflammatory and anti-allergic responses (inhibition of histamine from mast cells and 
basophils) are produced only at high levels of glucocorticoids. These effects cannot be produced by 
normal circulating glucocorticoids in the body and thus require exogenous supplementation of 
steroids to produce them. 737

questions.question: Question 8: ACTH level is higher during
questions.explanation:
ACTH level is higher during the early morning and low during late evening. 75% of the ACTH 
production occurs between 4:00 AM to 10:00 AM. Note: Cortisol levels are also high in the early morning and low in the late evening.

questions.question: Question 9: ACTH secretion is inhibited by
questions.explanation:
Glucocorticoids inhibit ACTH secretion by a direct negative feedback mechanism. They also 
inhibit CRH secretion.

questions.question: Question 10: Aldosterone secretion is maximally stimulated by
questions.explanation:
Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of 
aldosterone secretion. 738

questions.question: Question 11: Mineralocorticoid receptors are present in all except
questions.explanation:
Mineralocorticoid receptors are not present in the liver. They are present in kidneys, 
colon, hippocampus, salivary glands, and sweat glands. Mineralocorticoid activity increases the reabsorption of Na+ and potassium excretion from urine, 
sweat, saliva, and contents of the colon. Along with the Na+, there is water reabsorption and 
inturn ECF volume expansion.

questions.question: Question 12: In which of the following ways does aldosterone react with renal tubular cells?

options.a: Increases transport of ENaCs from the cytoplasm to the cell membrane
options.b: Binds to steroid receptor inside the nucleus of renal tubular cells
options.c: Binds to ENaC's on the cell membrane and increase Na+ transport
options.d: Binds to G-protien coupled receptors on the cell surface

questions.explanation:
Aldosterone increases transport of ENaCs (epithelial sodium channels) from the cytoplasm to the 
cell membrane. This is a rapid effect of aldosterone. Mechanism of action of aldosterone: • Aldosterone diffuses into the renal tubular epithelial cells and combines with a mineralocorticoid 
receptor (MR) in the cytoplasm. • The aldosterone-receptor complex diffuses into the nucleus and induces transcription. • The mRNA diffuses back into the cytoplasm and undergoes translation to form proteins. These 
have two effects - Rapid and Slow. • The slower effect is increase in synthesis of ENaCs. • The important products formed are: • Na+K+ATPase • membrane transport proteins like epithelial sodium channel 739

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following has the greatest effect on plasma osmolality?
questions.explanation:
Vasopressin (also called ADH or anti-diuretic hormone) has the greatest effect on plasma 
osmolality. Two primary systems are especially involved in regulating the concentration of sodium and 
osmolarity of extracellular fluid: • The osmoreceptor-ADH system and • The thirst mechanism. Although aldosterone decreases the rate of sodium excretion by the kidneys, the concentration of 
sodium in the extracellular fluid rises only by a few mEqs. The reason for this is that when sodium 
is reabsorbed by the tubules, simultaneous absorption of equivalent amounts of water occurs. So, 
aldosterone does not cause a significant change in the plasma osmolality. 740

questions.question:
Question 14: A 30-year-old man is admitted with nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. On evaluation, he is 
hypotensive and has mucosal hyperpigmentation. Laboratory workup reveals the diagnosis of 
hypoaldosteronism. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?
questions.explanation:
In a patient with hypoaldosteronism, alkalosis is least likely to be found. Hypoaldosteronism is 
rather responsible for causing metabolic acidosis. Patients with hypoaldosteronism have: • Hyponatremia- due to increased Na+ loss in urine • Hyperkalemia- due to K+ retention • Hypotension- due to reduced ECF volume • Mild metabolic acidosis because hydrogen ions are not secreted in the urine

questions.question:
Question 15: A 35-year-old female presents to the OPD with headaches and high blood pressure. On 
investigation, increased aldosterone levels with low renin levels are seen and a diagnosis of 
Conn's syndrome is made. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?

options.b: Rise of > 7meq/L in plasma Na+ level

questions.explanation:
Rise in plasma Na+ level of > 7meq/L than the normal value is least likely to be found in this 
patient. Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually a rise of 
less than 4-6 mEq/L. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in 
plasma sodium remaining fairly normal. Conn’s syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-producing tumour of 
the zona glomerulosa, causing: • Loss of potassium by the kidneys leads to hypokalemia. • Mild metabolic alkalosis. • A slight increase in extracellular fluid volume and blood volume. • A modest increase in plasma sodium concentration. • Hypertension. 741

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following decreases aldosterone secretion?
questions.explanation: Hypernatremia decreases aldosterone secretion.

questions.question:
Question 17: Hormones that are increased in plasma during periods of stress include all of the following 
except
questions.explanation:
Insulin does not increase during stress. In response to stress, the usual physiological functions like gluconeogenesis, lipolysis, and 
inhibition of insulin actions occurs, resulting in increased blood levels of fuel sources (glucose, 
fatty acids) needed to cope. 742 
Sold by @itachibot Hormones that are increased in the blood by stress are CRH, ACTH, cortisol, -endorphin(to 
reduce pain), vasopressin, aldosterone, growth hormone, and glucagon.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is the major adrenal androgen ?
questions.explanation:
Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) is the major adrenal androgen. The androgens secreted from the adrenal gland are dehydroepiandrosterone and 
androstenedione.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 16-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with hirsutism and masculinization. Which 
of the following hormones of the adrenal cortex is the likely culprit?
questions.explanation:
Hirsutism and masculinization in a female suggest excessive androgens like 
dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA). Adrenogenital syndrome is due to an adrenocortical tumor secreting excessive quantities of 
androgens that cause intense masculinizing effects. In boys, it presents as precocious puberty. In 
women, virile characteristics develop, including: • Growth of a beard • Deeper voice • Masculine distribution of hair on the body and the pubis and • Growth of the clitoris The excretion of 17-ketosteroids (which are derived from androgens) in the urine maybe 10 to 15 
times elevated. This finding can be used in diagnosing the disease. 743

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the 
ovaries of females?

options.c: Phosphate flux through the gastrointestinal epithelium is enhanced by vitamin D
options.d: Vit D decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules

questions.explanation:
DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the 
enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS. 90% of DHEA is synthesised by the adrenals and 10% comes from the ovaries. 744
